Author: zawy#5864
Content:
I haven't looked at your code yet.  What's frakenstein?  mixing  e^x on one side and SMAs on the other?    Yes that's a bit frakenstein, but it could work because e^x at small x is approximately 1+x so the linearity of the SMAs could be mathematically very close to the needed e^x functions.   So it may be that we need several EMAs on the  other side.  But I want to work out the symmetrical SMAs on both sides.

The path I've described above is a postulate. I'll eventualy do modelling to check the theory.   Trying different things by modelling until they work is a risky path. I have  used modelling only to refine constants because my estimates of the probabilities have some error.

Author: zawy#5864
Content:
you might need an SMA function that allows you to   send   timestamp vector and  target vector (if they're not "globally" available) and  pass N and a float or 2 integers for a fraction that is close to the float value  that will determine  the "divisor".   I think there should be a global variable that determines the aggresiveness of these modifications that new coins can choose. It will will adjust the float or fraction before passing it because it's invertde depending on if it's on the high side or low side.  Perfectly happy coins can effictively cancel this modification.
```
k = aggressiveness factor
bnTarget = max( SMA(N, divisor*k) for N=2, 4, 8 16 & their divisors,  min( SMA(N, divisor/k) foreach N and divisor, Digishield ));
```

Author: zawy#5864
Content: k = 1  could be what we think will be the fastest response while safe.  lower  k  in what I have above would be to make it less aggressive.

Author: zawy#5864
Content:
So....
```
k = aggressiveness factor
bnTarget = max( SMA(numerator, denominator*k, N) for N=2, 4, 8 16 & their divisors,  min( SMA(numerator*k, denominator, N)  foreach N and divisor, Digishield ));
```

Author: SHossain#0007

Author: zawy#5864
Content: It's possible @jl777c are close to completing it.    It's a tremendous advancement in DAs for 3 reasons.  First, I'm happy someone like JL was familar with my work on changing difficulty during the block. This idea goes back to a medium article by Andrew Stone (BTC Unlimited).   This was  the only way to unstick  1E6 hashrate increase problems.  1E6 required a lot more than a linear downward adjustment for long solvetimes. So JL was trying N^2.  But that decreases too quickly.  I knew to use 2^x aka e^x aka 3^x.   But like I was saying, things need to be symmetric which means we need to be able to rise as fast as we fall or a big attacker can get too many blocks way too quickly with persistent oscillations.  The 2^x function  can resolve enormous jumps in only 30 or so bocks.  I thought of small-window SMAs thought could do it without causing other problems.  I spent a lot of time in the past on these kind of increases  So we can rise and fall in response to any size hash attack in about 30 blocks, apparently being pretty symmetrica (30 blocks to rise, 30 blocks to fall) .  By any size I mean a 1 billion times increase in hashrate takes 50 blocks to fix whereas Zcash's default digishiled (that this still uses for normal hashrates) takes 500 blocks to address a 1000x increase.    It's nice working with JL because I didn't have to look at the code.
